01.text: This is the beginning of a new part of the story that runs through [[:en:bible:notes:mat:18:34|18:35]], where Jesus teaches about life in the kingdom of heaven. Here, Jesus uses a little child to teach the disciples.
"Who is the most important" or "Who among us will be the most important" (UDB)

The phrase "kingdom of heaven" refers to God's rule as king. This phrase is used only in the book of Matthew. If possible, keep "heaven" in your translation. AT: "in God's kingdom" or "when our God in heaven establishes his rule on earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"I tell you the truth." This adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.

01.ref: unless you turn ... you will in no way enter
01.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "you must change ... in order to enter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

Jesus uses a simile to teach the disciples that they should not be concerned with who is most important. They should be concerned with becoming humble like a child. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

The phrase "kingdom of heaven" refers to God's rule as king. This phrase is used only in the book of Matthew. If possible, keep "heaven" in your translation. AT: "enter God's kingdom" or "belong to our God in heaven when he establishes his rule on earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

04.text: Jesus continues teaching the disciples that they need to be humble like a child if they want to be important in God's kingdom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"is the most important" or "will be the most important"

The phrase "kingdom of heaven" refers to God's rule as king. This phrase is used only in the book of Matthew. If possible, keep "heaven" in your translation. AT: "in God's kingdom" or "when our God in heaven establishes his rule on earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "my name" refers to the entire person. AT: "because of me" or "because he is my disciple" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jesus means it is the same as welcoming him. AT: "it is like he is welcoming me" and "it is as if he were welcoming me"

04.ref: a great millstone should be hung about his neck, and that he should be sunk into the depths of the sea
04.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "if someone put a great millstone around his neck and threw him into the deep sea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a large, heavy, circular stone used for grinding wheat grain into flour. AT: "a heavy stone"

07.text: Jesus continues to use a little child to teach the disciples and warns against the terrible consequences of causing children to sin.
Here "world" refers to people. AT: "to the people of the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "stumbling" is a metaphor for sin. AT: "because of the things that cause people to sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"that those things come that cause people to sin"

07.ref: the person through whom those times come
07.text: "any person who causes others to sin"

07.ref: If your hand or your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off and throw it away from you
07.text: Jesus uses a hyperbole here to emphasize how serious he is. Jesus means a person must do anything necessary to remove from their lives what causes them to sin. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

All occurrences of these words are singular. Jesus is speaking to all people in general. It may be more natural for your language to translate with a plural "you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

07.ref: than to be thrown into the eternal fire having two hands or two feet
07.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "than to have both hands and feet when God throws you into the eternal fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

09.ref: If your eye causes you to stumble, pluck it out and throw it away from you
09.text: Jesus uses a hyperbole here to emphasize how serious he is. Jesus means a person must do anything necessary to remove from their lives what causes them to sin. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Here "stumble" is a metaphor for sin. AT: "causes you to sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

All occurrences of these words are singular. Jesus is speaking to all people in general. It may be more natural for your language to translate with a plural "you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

09.ref: than to be thrown into the eternal fire having both eyes
09.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "than to have both eyes when God throws you into the eternal fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

10.ref: you do not despise any of these little ones
10.text: "you do not think of these little ones as being unimportant." This can be stated in positive form. AT: "you show respect to these little ones"
This add emphasis to what Jesus says next.

10.ref: that in heaven their angels always look on the face of my Father who is in heaven
10.text: Jewish teachers taught that only the most important angels could be in God's presence. Jesus means that the most important angels speak to God about these little ones. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

10.ref: always look on the face of my Father
10.text: This is an idiom that means they are in God's presence. AT: "are always close to my Father" or "are always in the presence of my Father" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an important title for God that describes the relationship between God and Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

12.text: Jesus continues to use a little child to teach the disciples and tells a parable to explain God's care for people.
Jesus uses this question to get people's attention. AT: "Think of how people act" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion|Rhetorical Question]])
All occurrences of these words are plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

12.ref: If anyone ... that did not go astray
12.text: Jesus uses a parable to teach his disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])
Jesus uses a question to teach his disciples. AT: "he will always leave ... astray" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion|Rhetorical Question]])
"I tell you the truth." This adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.

12.ref: it is not the will of your Father in heaven that one of these little ones should perish
12.text: This can be stated in a positive form. AT: "Your Father in heaven wants all of these little ones to live"
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

15.text: Jesus begins to teach his disciples about forgiveness and reconciliation.
This refers to a fellow believer in God, not a physical brother.

15.ref: you will have gained your brother
15.text: "you will have made your relationship with your fellow believer good again"

15.ref: so that by the mouth of two or three witnesses every word might be verified
15.text: Here "mouth" and "word" refer to what a person says. This can be stated in active form. AT: "so that two or three witnesses may verify that what you say about your fellow believer is true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

15.ref: by the mouth of two or three witnesses every word might be verified
15.text: Jesus is referring to one of the laws that Moses gave the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

17.ref: if he refuses to listen to them
17.text: "if your fellow believer refuses to listen to the witnesses who came with you"

17.ref: let him be to you as a Gentile and a tax collector
17.text: "treat him as you would treat a Gentile or tax collector." This implies that they should remove him from the community of believers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

18.text: "I tell you the truth." This adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.
All occurrences of this word are plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

This metaphor means that God in heaven will approve of what Peter allows or forbids on earth. See how you translated these in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:16:19|16:19]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

18.ref: will be bound ... will be released
18.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will bind ... God will release" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.
It is implied that Jesus means "if at least two of you" or "if two or more of you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These refer to the "two of you." AT: "you ... you"
This is an important title for God that describes the relationship between God and Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
It is implied that Jesus means "two or more" or "at least two." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "name" refers to the entire person. AT: "because of me" or "because they are my disciples" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

21.text: Possible meanings are 1) "70 times 7" (ULB) or 2) "77 times" (UDB). If using a number would be confusing, you can translate it as "more times than you can count" or "you must always forgive him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

23.text: Jesus uses a parable to teach about forgiveness and reconciliation.

23.ref: the kingdom of heaven is similar
23.text: This introduces a parable. See how you translated a similar parable introduction in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:24|13:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

23.ref: to settle accounts with his servants
23.text: "his servants to pay him what they owed"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone brought one of the king's servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"10,000 talents" or "more money than the servant could ever repay" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

23.ref: his master commanded him to be sold ... and payment to be made
23.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the king commanded his servants to sell the man ... and to pay the debt with the money from the sale" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

26.text: This shows that the servant approached the king in the most humble way possible. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

28.text: Jesus continues telling a parable to his disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])
"100 denarii" or "one hundred days' wages" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"The first servant grasped his fellow servant"

This shows that the servant approached the king in the most humble way possible. See how you translated these phrases in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:18:26|18:26]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

30.text: Jesus continues telling a parable to his disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

30.ref: he went and threw him into prison
30.text: "the first servant went and threw his fellow servant into prison"

32.text: Jesus continues telling a parable to his disciple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

32.ref: Then that servant's master called him
32.text: "Then the king called the first servant"
The king uses a question to scold the first servant. AT: "You should have ... you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

34.text: Jesus concludes his parable about forgiveness and reconciliation.
This is the end of the part of the story that began in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:18:01|18:1]], where Jesus teaches about life in the kingdom of heaven.
"gave him over." Most likely the king himself did not take the first servant to the torturers. AT: "he ordered his servants to give him over" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "that the first servant owed the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is an important title for God that describes the relationship between God and Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
All occurrences of these words are plural. Jesus is speaking to his disciples, but this parable teaches a general truth that applies to all believers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This is an idiom. AT: "sincerely" or "completely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
